with all of that selling apple is still Buffet's number one holding it's worth about $70 billion and about 25% of his overall portfolio but obviously that was a disgusting amount of selling there in apple stock and really the biggest reason for that I feel is because uh really just how much Apple has already risen skyrocketing to a new all-time high in recent years to now being literally the most expensive stock in the world by market cap at over uh $3.8 trillion now look I own a little bit of Apple stock myself and I love how sticky and profitable their business is but when you're trading over half a trillion dollars more than Microsoft and over a trillion dollars more than Google Google and Amazon too I can totally understand wanting to take some profits at those levels in fact if I was given a choice at today's prices I would rather have any of those other three stocks over Apple so it's not surprising to me and of course I'm talking about Amazon Microsoft and Google and so it's not surprising to me here to be doing some trimming there at these levels it's just a little shocking by how much buffit really sold which I think was also a bet on the market overall just being too and the first of those was actually a brand new addition to the portfolio it was in pool Corp ticker symbol pool p ool l which was a purchase of more than $150 million now if you've never heard of this one guys they're a very large holesale swimming pool and supplies and services company in fact they're technically the largest in the world not only selling pools but you know of course installing them maintaining them and even repairing them too as well as just selling all the all of the supplies that Pool owners might need you know might not be the most exciting type of business out there but being a market leader in a niche kind of you know area like that has actually led to a lot of success for the company unfortunately though being that dominant in your Market well it also leaves you pretty vulnerable to the macroeconomy when you're doing so well in your Niche kind of area macroeconomy can really affect your business and we saw a direct example of that in their sales that soared around the start of the pandemic because of all the stimulus money going into people's pockets and that made it easier for them to you know renovate their homes maybe install a new pool or fix and upgrade their existing one but then as soon as all of that stimulus ran out and we were left with high inflation and high interest rates where the economy obviously took a dive people struggled more and P's Revenue came falling right back down with an 11% drop last year and another 4% drop expected this year too for their sales you know having some cyclicality it could be I would say fine though for a warm Buffet type of value dividend kind of stock because if the price Falls well it can drag that valuation down and send the dividend Rising which are all things that Buffett really loves to have in his you know type of stocks we always see that with Buffett stocks value and dividends and things like that so being volatile having that exposure to the macroeconomy may not be the worst thing but while this one does have a strong business as the market leader the other two variables are really lacking here in terms of valuation and dividend as even though the stock price fell by about 40% recently their forward p ratio still hovers around 60 to 80% higher than the sector while the dividend despite having some excellent growth metrics on it only yields less than 1.4% meaning that it would likely take years until it even is able to grow large enough to keep up with inflation so I'm not a big fan of this one myself guys and I actually just put out a best dividend stocks video for 2025 where I listed many different value dividend stocks that I think are much more attractive than this one I'll be nice though and rank it at number three for now because we still need to see what else is on this list but it's not a stock that I'll be picking up myself

well coming in at purchase number two though we actually have the other brand new pickup from Buffett which has also been getting a lot more attention recently and that is the pizza giant dominoes SEC symbol dpz which he purchased almost $550 million of last quarter now when it comes to Domino's business I tend to avoid these types of fast food kind of retail stocks myself just because of how saturated and competitive the market is making it a little harder to keep up with everything going on there however I will say that on a more personal level I'm actually a fan of dominoes and their brand out of all the fast food pizza shops Domino's is actually my favorite I like to taste more than like Pizza Hut or Little Caesars and the online app is super easy to use where I can customize everything I usually do like a handmade pan pizza with alfredo sauce mushrooms and and chicken maybe some pineapple I I this is starting to sell like a commercial for Pizza Hut but I I uh for dominoes I mean but I have actually used them in the past and it was a good experience and they also tend to have a lot of coupons too that makes it a little more affordable so just the overall experience I've been a fan of with Domino's personally just me but uh you know I I'm not the only one I'm guessing because Domino's has actually grown into the number one market share leader as a franchiser with still more room to grow in the future given the roughly $95 billion estimated Market size worldwide which they have a pretty large presence in across more than 90 different Global markets plus their new more initiative will launch another 5,000 new stores in the coming years to help keep their already large growth rates versus the competition many of which have actually been in Decline throughout recent years however for as good as Domino's performs in relation to their peers their overall growth as a company itself is still too low in my opinion to justify the valuation now the stock has actually dipped a little from the top losing about a quarter of its value but even here it still trades around 30 to 50% more expensive than the sector based on PE and Peg ratios that's just not going to cut it for a business that is only growing sales by around a mid single digit percentage on average nor is the really small dividend of less than a 1.5% yield now granted that dividend does at least have some excellent growth metrics on it so perhaps Buffett was looking for just another kind of market leader with a growing dividend similar to pool what we saw with pool right but like I said before I just think that there's way better options out there for any of the attributes that we're talking about here and for that reason I'm ranking them number three giving them just a slight Edge over pool since I've at least bought from Dominoes on occasion I I want to eat healthier so you know dominoes is not really something I eat often but you know the fact that I have used it before would probably make it a little easier to keep track of the business and their operations and understand them a little better than something like pool cuz I don't even have a pool

thankfully purchase number three is actually one that I own myself and that is verisign taker symbol vrs n which he just picked up another 234,000 more shares of now making up over $2.5 billion in the portfolio at just under 1% and yeah this one I do actually like a lot verisign is the largest internet top level domain provider in the world basically managing and securing the infrastructure behind. net.edu and other similar domains which are provided to other companies for a recurring fee it's not a stock that gets talked about very often in the mainstream but it's a great overall business that I feel is very sticky and not likely to ever go away as such financials are typically strong with consistent mid single digit growth every year and while their growth rates are not anything special to send the stock skyrocketing in the future I do feel that they're at least reliable enough to keep the stock performing well long term plus the recent dip of about 20% left it trading cheaper than their own 5-year average and the sector median by around the same amount on a gap PE basis which I feel is very attractive for a proven leader like this if I was to be really kind of picky about verisign though I would probably say that it's just a little too boring of a business of a stock to not be paying any dividends but for what it is I think it's a good enough value type of stock to hold long term so I'm ranking them higher at number two because of it

and coming in at number four we have another one here that's been getting some Buzz lately and that is Sirius XM ticker symbol S at a 12 million shares increase bringing the stake up to over 2.8 billion and worth just over 1% of Buffett's overall portfolio unfortunately though one of the reasons why it's been getting talked about so much is because of how much the stock has actually cratered in recent years which I can understand the interest in that you know being negative over the past decade while also losing about 70% of its value from the top leaving behind a dirt cheap valuation on practically any metric you look at while also raising the dividend yield up to over 4% all of that alone would normally be you know something attractive to to consider however that's only if the business is stable enough to help the stock recover long term which it could be but I personally have never had much faith in Sirius now you guys know the business here they're basically the only name worth talking about in satellite radio this coming after after the 2008 merger of Sirius with XM radio before later acquiring Pandora as well to form what many thought would be an entertainment Powerhouse especially back in the day when Pandora was a lot more popular a lot of people used it to stream music for free he coupled that with Sirius XM which was always this kind of like premium Radio Service had higher quality it was often bundled on uh infotainment systems on newer cars so it was always kind of like this thing that felt like it would be the future of radio and stuff like that this is back in the day when these Services were very popular but you fast forward to present time and the market has really largely shifted away towards other massive brands in online streaming like Spotify Apple music YouTube music Amazon music and even 10cent music in China Guys these are some of the absolute largest companies in the entire world so they can afford to subsidize their streaming services to gain market share and that's exactly what happened over the years now statista doesn't list serious uh numbers on this page cuz they consider satellite to be a separate Market in itself even though I would lump it all together as direct competition but for comparison you know Spotify currently has like over 250 million subscribers with most of the others hovering around 100 million too but sirius on the other hand it only has around like 40 million paid uh that's if you combine it with Pandora so around half the size of most of the competition while Pandora has also been losing millions of subscribers in recent years too but overall that's caused their financials to struggle with three years of slight Revenue declines now expected with just about flat profitability too last quarter their free cash flow even plummeted by over 60% which I'm sure was mostly due to the recent restructurings that they did with Liberty Media but overall it just feels like a very up in theair type of business with also massive competition to where it's just too difficult to predict prct where they'll end up long term so I'm ranking them at the bottom here at number four uh since I would at least have stronger faith in the other businesses instead

with that said though we're left now with the final purchase of the list and it's a buffet stock that I've covered a lot before in the past and I'm also not a big fan of it and I'm also uh really feeling the sickness right now so I'm just going to do a really rapid fire of this one do it really quick before you guys finish off this video but uh that is the oil giant ocidental petroleum ticker symbol oxy which he continues to add more of bringing the stake up to over12 billion and worth over 45% of his portfolio but as I've said many times Buffett really got special shares and dividends with this stock for having help them acquire another oil giant called anad Darko and that has since resulted in Buffett being able to collect massive dividends from the stock even when they cut that dividend for regular shareholders nothing against oxy but in my opinion it's just a fairly boring overall Oil stock with an even richer valuation than the sector and a mediocre dividend of only less than 2% for that price I'd rather buy something like Chevron who at least pays a dividend of above 4 and a half% if I really want to have an oil stock so I'm actually going to rank oxy even lower than Sirius because of how expensive it is
